Params[3]: Snow was coming down hard that day, as he remembers it.
Disconnected by the fires of war, the train has come to a stop and fallen silent in the snow.
He has stains of Rachel's blood on his hand. They're lukewarm at best—yet he's feeling a burning sensation coming from them.
Rachel... Capt...
The sound of people's footsteps coming from below hit him like thunders.
Why...
Like a ghost looming ever closer upon him, the clouds in the skies are growing thicker and darker by the second.
He's killed his mentor, and no amount of regret can undo what's happened. The only thing he can feel now is the throbs coming from his heart that remind him of what he's done.
All that he's held dearly and hated so much, and all that the train once was and would have been... will no longer be.
Why... did I do that?
With the world growing dark, shards of memories rain down like broken glasses.
Why...? Captain...
When did all this happen?
...Tell me, please.
Why?
He was 12 then, and autumn had just come.
Her icy-cold face is a sharp contrast against the hot air around her. Noan's mother is sitting in her workspace and staring at the people around her through her inscrutable mask.
We've got an order to look into the issue with the financial reports and resources.
...Who are you people?
I'm one of Sir Aston's personal guards, and this is my ID.
The man whose face can't be made out calls up a document from his terminal.
We'll have to do this forcibly if you refuse to cooperate.
Noan's mother falls silent looking at the document—but moments later, she stands up from the old wooden chair.
Fine. I'll go with you.
...Mom?
Stay here. I'll be right back.
Little does he know that this is an empty promise.
When the boy still hasn't seen his mother back home the next day, he starts going around asking people where she went.
Your mom? She got busted doin' her little tricks with financial reports or pocketing resources. Hahaha!
What's so... funny about that?
Get this—because she had it comin'.
Dude, stop. Kid knows nothing.
Well, he brought it up himself.
I always found her fishy. It's not like I have evidence or anything, but given the nature of the position, I'm sure as hell she was up to something.
Oh and, lest we forget, she's "his" wife, right?
Noan...
Ed, where is she...
Boy... ain't nothing I can say now. People are all saying they've found evidence against her. They just don't know who she's been working for.
I'd put my money on Ashlar! Julie was one of them to begin with, and she even married one of 'em aristocrats. Sucks that her husband died before they even got to enjoy themselves, though.
With the lower level being the way it is now, it only makes sense that she'd do anything to join their ranks again.
Ed, do you know where she is? Can I go to see her?
With Ed's instructions, Noan wanders around—before he finally arrives at the middle section of Asslam. People call this section the cargo car before it's got piles of items sitting around.
That's when Noan sees his mother sitting in a small storage space that's faintly lit, surrounded by some guards. She looks worn out.
Mom...?
Julie raises her head slowly when she hears Noan calling her name.
What happened?
Is everything they said about what you've done true?
Do you trust me?
I do, of course...
She lets out a faint smile from behind her mask.
That's all I'm asking.
What does that mean?
Mom...
Why? Why do you never tell me anything?
Frustrated and unable to stand the wall of silence that stands in between them, Noan fires his question at the inscrutable mask.
Those people were all laughing when they found out you'd been arrested, Mom...
And that's how they've always been—they'd say all sorts of mean things about you whenever they saw me. Do you know what they said?
When he opens his mouth, however, none of what he's heard comes out of it. He only manages to squeeze out toned-down versions of what they said.
You always say that we should trust and try to help out one another, Mom. But look at them...
What exactly have you done? Why are they being like this to you?
Don't cry, Noan.
But I'm not...!
Right. You need to hold your tears.
Tears are useless. Tears help no one.
Why are you here?
Is everything they said about you true...?
Yeah.
Did you really do those things?
Yeah.
Why?
It's all for a better tomorrow.
...I don't understand.
It's fine, because you will in time.
It's true that I've crossed the line, but if what I did brings about a better tomorrow for the people, I'd gladly do it again and pay the price.
My only concern... would be you.
Noan, do you still trust me?
I want to...!
Great. That's enough, because I care about you more than I do anyone else.
...Do you really care about me?
Of course.
Why did you do all that, then? Why do you never eat around me? And why do you never take off your mask?
You always criticize my hobbies when you don't even understand the books I read.
When they called you a monster or witch... I had no idea how to hit them with a comeback, because I don't even know what you look like!
Mom, do you really care about me...?
Or am I just... am I just a burden to you?
Have you always felt that way?
Yes.
Why did you never tell me?
I did, but you never listened.
When are you coming back, Mom?
...I'm sorry.
This is the first time Noan hears his mother apologize—and, for a second, he thought he heard it wrong.
...Why are you apologizing?
He knows only too well that his mother isn't going to give in.
Just because, Noan.
She says his name in a trembling tone.
...There is just something I wanted to tell you before it's too late.
With Noan's eyes on her, Julie slowly removes her mask.

Her face is full of scars and her eyes appear soulless—telltale signs of what years of hard work and struggle have done to her. All the more bizarre are her hands—which are a blue-purple, a sharp contrast against her overly white nails.
Do you still recognize me?
Mom.
This is his answer to her question, because he does recognize his mother—there is no way he wouldn't recognize this face that's so indefinitely similar to his.
Are you scared?
No, I'm not... I just want to know what happened.
I don't have time to tell you that, but I just hope... I just hope that you live on knowing the facts and knowing what I truly think of you.
These scars and this situation I'm caught up in are what I got for the mistakes I made... and the way I've always been treating you is one of them.
...I always treat people "nicely" my own way, thinking that they'll eventually come to see things my way...
Which is why I've put on this mask and left you at home by yourself, because I didn't want those people out there to hurt you, but I guess what I did only ended up hurting you.
Every time I rip your paintings apart or see you get into fights with them...

I just can't stop picturing what life would have been like for you if you were born into a family that fared better... I'm sure you'd have been able to grow up a normal kid not having to worry about your next meal, and you'd have been able to draw anything you liked.
It always kills me to think I was the one bringing you to this hellhole, but I've never for a second regretted keeping you right by my side.
Noan, you're a strong and wonderful kid.
Which is why I think you probably understand why I got in your way of pursuing your hobby. You'd have ended up being all delusional and lost in this world if I didn't.
Mom...
I mean, I guess I could have been nicer about it, but it was never easy trying to convince you.
...But like mother, like son, I suppose.
Her eyes are brimming with regret—as though trying to say that "standing by what you believe in" is a personal shortcoming she was never able to overcome.
I know exactly what those people have been saying about it, but I always tell myself to just look the other way.
...And I thought you'd be able to do the same.
But how could I?!
Well, I guess that's just something you'll have to learn how to do from now on.
I know they've been calling you a monster, Noan, but a monster doesn't have to be horrifying or doomed. You might not be able to get rid of that label, but still...
I hope you grow up to be just like "Shrek" and live happily ever after.
...Have you read those books?
I was crazy about them as a kid... Guess I should have told you sooner, yeah?
Better late than never.
Except it's too late now.
Why do you say that?
Why?
I guess it's because... because it finally hit me that there is only so much I can do, and that I'm just going to keep blundering the harder I try to right the wrongs I caused.
And there are just too many things that we can't fix anymore... given how far we've already come.
Mom, please...

I've stored all the resources in a box that I left under the bed at home, and I've taped the key to the interlayer of one of the drawers in my office desk. They won't last you for long, though, so you need to use them wisely—until Rachel comes back.
What about you?
I'm going to have to stay here.
Because of what you did...?
Do you think what I did was wrong?
The boy nods his head heavily.
...Right.
Let's apologize to people, Mom. We can start over after that.
...I've lost my chance to.
I wasn't able to become the person I wanted to be... The only thing I've ever done is compromise with my pathetic self so I could look away from all the things I couldn't accomplish.
I thought that would help, but I guess it was all just wishful thinking...
See... a single blunder is all that it has to take... for someone to hit the rock bottom of hell.
Que sera sera—this is just a fat lie the survivors want you to believe.
Seeing the guards coming this way from the distance, she lets out a sigh as she picks up her pace of speaking.
Luck, power, courage, knowledge, and wise decisions—these are all the things you need to become a survivor, and that's why it's hard to be one. Now...
Noan, I hope you get to grow up and survive the apocalypse... I hope you get to become who you want to be.
And... if you still think what I did was wrong many, many years from now, then remember to never do what I did, okay?
Time's up. You need to go.
Julie puts her mask back on her face and waves at Noan.
Do you still remember the lullaby? Now... the sun is out. It's time to say goodbye.
Goodbye... Noan, goodbye.
Dragged away by the guards, the boy finally realizes that this is the moment of farewell.
There are so many things that he hasn't cleared up with his mother, and there are so many things that he wanted to ask—except he's lost his chance forever.

In the last 12 short years of Noan's life, they've never once had a heart-to-heart conversation. All the dodging, hiding, and blaming over the years dug a trench so deep in between them—that he never once had a chance to see his mother's true colors.

Her past, her aspirations, her worries, her longings—not once was he given a chance to learn about any of these, and it's only now that he finally learns of his mother's love for him for the first time.
Why are you only telling me all these now? You never even gave us a chance to fix our relationship!
No, Mom! I'm not leaving! There are a million things you haven't told me yet!
...Noan...
Just go already! It's against the rule to even let you in here in the first place, for God's sake!
No!
He tries to break free. Just a few more seconds will do, he thinks—except all the struggling gets him nothing but violence in return.
Stay put, damn it!
Ugh...!
I'm sorry...
The guards throw Noan back to the Commoner Carriage unconscious and lock him up.
The night after, a Cargo Crew member shows up to announce Julie's death.
The doctor ruled food poisoning to be the cause of her death, maintaining that she'd consumed expired, rotten food—which is a common cause of death among people living on the lower level.
Is that even possible?

He stands helplessly among everyone, awash in remorse and guilt. People, however, offer him no constructive answers to his questions. Instead, they shower him—this boy who's been a loner that puts up a tough front—with cold, piercing looks.
Before despair tears his soul into pieces, the boy once again finds hope in his book storage.
With the information the terminal turns up, he slowly teases apart every last detail from that fateful day.
Umpteen hours later, he finally comes across an entry that reads "nitrite poisoning"—and a symptom of it is "cyanosis", reminding the boy of his mother's purplish fingers before she died.
Is this what killed her?
The boy can't be sure.
Not long after Julie's death, those men that introduced themselves as "Aston's personal guards" share their findings into the case—which, unsurprisingly, are exactly as people have guessed.
They maintain that Julie was working together with some aristocrats and Cargo Crew members, and that, together, they pocketed a sizable amount of resources.

And that's as far as they went looking into the case—because Julie died during her trial, which made it impossible for them to find out where the pocketed resources are. Furthermore, the Cargo Crew members that had worked with her all went poof, erasing every last hint that might help.
All these people pay steep prices, save for the aristocrats that worked with her.
The mastermind's name has become an open secret—which, however, doesn't seem to change a thing on the train.
And then a month goes by.

The boy did try to be as economical as he could with what little food he had, but still found himself reaching the end of it just 15 days after his mother left. Having no other choice, he decides to leave his wooden bed of a "home" to seek help.
He comes across quite a few people who, in addition to hating his mother's guts for "having worked with those from the upper level", also despise him—for the mere fact that he's her son.
Fortunately, however, he also comes across people who are willing to stand with him, having been helped in their hour of need by his mother.
She might have been in the wrong, but I still have her to thank... or else I wouldn't have been here today.
Here, take this. It's not a whole lot, but that's about as much as I have. Try to get through the day first, son...
Noan, my mom wanted to give this to you for keeping me safe the other day.
With all the food he's scraped together, Noan manages to keep his head above water until Rachel comes back to the train from an emergency mission.
Not a day has gone by that he forgot the look on Rachel's face that day...
Rachel is always collected—but at this very moment, she's biting her teeth together and clenching her fists so hard that she doesn't even let go when her nails dig into her hands.
Noan was going to ask her what brought his mother to the bitter end she'd met, but nothing comes out of his mouth.
Because he's certain that the pain she's feeling is anything but feigned.
...Rachel...
I'm sorry... I'd have totally done everything I could to keep Julie safe... if I hadn't had to go on that emergency mission...
...But it's all too late now.
She looks down at her fist—with all the horrendous nail marks.
You'll be my apprentice starting today.
I'll train you and teach you to protect yourself.
You have to live on, Noan!
And you'll free everyone from this oppression! You'll lay the dead to rest yourself and let them know their sacrifices are not for naught!
Rachel holds Noan's shoulders with so much force that he feels on the verge of being crushed.
You need to live on, Noan, even if days like this go on for another four, five decades!
Noan nods earnestly to her words, having not fully realized the weight they hold.
Yes, I'll stick by your side and free everyone from this oppression, Rachel! And I'll be there to see their souls rest in peace at the end of it all!
...But.

Params[1]: Things don't turn out quite as they expected...

Params[3]: We'll be moving up to the roof and train there starting today. We don't have time to wait for your body to catch up anymore, and you'll have to learn how to cope with fights using techniques.
Roger that!

Params[1]: He hasn't slacked for a single moment. Still, his mother's words have dawned on him...

Params[3]: Faster, Noan! Faster!
Try again!

Params[1]: ...That he is as normal a human being as can be.
He has to do it the same way hundreds of thousands of people do it—through blood and sweat, with no shortcut in between.

Params[3]: Are you trying to drag us all down, Noan?!
Julie's dead, and you're gonna starve and die if you stop now!
I know.
Then pick up your pace and be the best version of yourself!
Alrighty.
I'll be away on a mission with the Cargo Crew for a month, and you have exactly a month to meet the goal I've set for you.
Yes, Captain!
Sure you can do it?
Of course!

Params[1]: When the thunders of wind come together to tear down what little was left of his fantasy, the boy breaks down in despair, no longer able to curb the heart-wrenching pain he feels within.

Params[3]: AAAGGHHH...!
He hates his hands' guts for being as weak as they are, but he has no idea how to make them stronger.
I don't want to drag people down!
Before he knows it, the boy has exhausted himself from crying. He closes his eyes, trying to preserve what little energy he still has.
I'm sorry... but I've lost my chance. I wasn't able to become the person I wanted to be... The only thing I've ever done is compromise with my pathetic self.
Mom...
Julie once told him that this is what it's like growing up, and that it's every normal person's job to learn to compromise.
But just how is he supposed to—when his heart burns so furiously with sadness and regret?
The boy doesn't aspire to be better, but he knows that he would give it all to take another step forward to alleviate himself of his pain somehow.
...Just you all wait and see... I'm not giving up...
